data.title: 2d particle effect rotation and better scaling
data.body:
Particle emitters can now be rotated. To achieve this, I made particles use a local transform (position, scale, rotation). The sprite's transform is then set to the world transform of the particle, using the transform of the parent (the emitter).  Here is a [small demo](https://imgur.com/a/z9bL0).

The editor has been updated to allow for rotation and scaling of the effect.

I originally planned to add rotation only, but since I was using a `Matrix3` for the parent transform, adding scale was easy. In fact, I believe this way of scaling is much simpler and works better than the current `scaleEffect` API which scales every parameter related to position/movement, and always felt more like a workaround.

I know that this is a significant change, so I would understand if it can't be merged. 

If it can however, please let me know if I should also push [that other commit](https://github.com/FredGithub/libgdx/commit/bc8a26fd76f1ed852349b041940c3b732782ab44), which reduces code complexity quite a bit by removing everything related to the current `scaleEffect`. Removing various public APIs (and the work of other people) is not the best though, but having 2 APIs for scaling is also not ideal. Not sure what to do at that point.

gdx-setup.jar finds a non-existent version of the build-tools
data.body:
Hello
#### Issue details
gdx-setup.jar finds a non-existent version of the build-tools.

#### Reproduction steps/code
* Install Android Studio 2.3.3 and build tools 26.0.2
* run java -jar gdx-setup 
* check Android box
* generate

Output:
IllegalStateException: Failed to find Build Tools revision 27.0.2

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [X ] Android
- [ ] iOS (robovm)
- [ ] iOS (MOE)
- [ ] HTML/GWT
- [ ] Windows
- [ ] Linux
- [ ] MacOS

#### Cause
There are next lines in  file "Android/Sdk/build-tools/26.0.2/source.properties"
-----
#Pkg.Revision=27.0.2
Pkg.Revision=26.0.2
----

#### Possible solution: 
ignore comments (lines starting with #) in the 
"private static String readBuildToolsVersion (File parentFile)" function 
in the file "libgdx/extensions/gdx-setup/src/com/badlogic/gdx/setup/GdxSetup.java".

data.title: Gdx setup for Robovm, MOE backend should use Asset Catalog for App Icon
data.body:
#### Issue details

Details discussed in https://github.com/MobiVM/robovm/issues/210

The Robovm app generated by the GDX setup utility (and probably also the MOE variant) use CFBundleIcons in Info.plist.xml to define app-icons available.

Since the Xcode 9 release (and related App Store upgrades) this is no longer supported; asset catalog AppIocn needs to be used.

#### Reproduction steps/code

* Generate a new libgdx project with ios (Robovm backend)
* Register app id in iTunes Connect, Apple Member Center.
* Submit the app.

It will fail with the following error:

    Missing Info.plist value - A value for the "Info.plist" key CFBundleIconName is missing in the 
     bundle 'com.rosapp.choinkafull'. Apps that provide icons in the asset catalog must also provide 
    this Info.plist key. For more information see 
    http://help.apple.com/xcode/mac/current/#/dev10510b1f7.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
All versions (Xcode / App Store change)

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [ ] Android
- [x] iOS (robovm)
- [x] iOS (MOE)
- [ ] HTML/GWT
- [ ] Windows
- [ ] Linux
- [ ] MacOS

Make TangentialAcceleration and PolarAcceleration respect the global setting
data.body:
Before this change, if a TangentialAcceleration or PolarAcceleration were used, the forces they'd apply particles didn't account for the location of the ParticleController. So if the ParticleController was moved or rotated, the TangentialAcceleration and PolarAcceleration both still acted as if the ParticleController hadn't been translated or rotated. 
After this change, if isGlobal is false, the direction of the PolarAcceleration's force is rotated when the ParticleController is and the axis about which TangentialAcceleration is applied is rotated. The particle to which the force is being applied is treated with its position relative to the ParticleController rather than relative to the origin. 
Tangential and Polar acceleration didn't respect the global/relative setting in Flame. this fixes https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/issues/4894

Additionally, when using a controller of controllers, it is necessary to pass on the rotation information.

In order to test, I have added three tests: TangentialAccelerationTest.java, PolarAccelerationTest.java and ParticleControllerInfluencerSingleTest.java.
 The behavior before this change can be seen if isGlobal is set to true in either of the first two cases. In the final case, the correctly rotated ParticleController is shown. All 3 tests were based on ParticleControllerTest.java.

data.title: OpenAL Music getPosition reports incorrect values after playing then stopping then playing again
3d particle TangentialAcceleration axis doesn't rotate when ParticleController is rotated
data.body:
[MyGdxGame.java.txt](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/files/1326660/MyGdxGame.java.txt)
Please ensure you have given all the following requested information in your report.

#### Issue details
I have a 3d ParticleController which makes use of a TangentialAcceleration dynamics modifier. When the ParticleEffect is at the origin, the effect gives the appearance of a tornado where the axis of the tornado is the z-axis.
The TangentialAcceleration is not set to global.
If the ParticleController is translated, the tangential acceleration is applied to the particles as if the origin is still the center of the particle effect. If the particle effect is rotated such that the axis of the tornado is no longer (parallel to) the y-axis, the tangential acceleration is still applied using the y-axis. 
The desired effect is that translating or rotating the ParticleController should result in the tornado still remaining as a tornado, but that its center and orientation would change. 
#### Reproduction steps/code
I've attached a file (remove the .txt extension I was forced to add for the upload and it's a valid java file) which demonstrates the issue. At lines 91 and 92, if there is no rotation or translation (comment out lines 91 and 92), then the particles look somewhat like a tornado which has its center axis aligned with the z-axis (which is where the camera is). However, if the particle controller is translated and/or rotated, the tangential acceleration is still applied. Note that isGlobal is set to false, so the expected behavior is that the acceleration would be applied with respect to the center of the particle controller, not with respect to point (0,0,0).

Is this behavior intentional? If so, why does it make sense that the tangential acceleration only appears as it does in the Flame editor when the controller is unrotated and at the origin?

If not, would a reasonable fix be to store the center of the particle controller and the rotation, and apply the rotation to TMP_V3 in TangentialAcceleration.upate() and to subtract the center of the particle controller from the positionChannel values before performing the cross product?

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
LibGDX version 1.9.6. I also pulled the code from git on 09/23/2017 and the issue is present there as well. 

#### Stacktrace
There's no stacktrace. The code runs fine.

#### Please select the affected platforms
I only tested on Linux, but I would be surprised if this was platform specific

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29168257/libgdx-how-to-rotate-the-emmition-trail-of-a-3d-particle seems to be a similar issue

[Feature Request] Stop using "private" modifiers
data.body:
#### Issue details
LibGDX is a great OSS, but some class are designed with Java best practice, that may not fit well in OSS model, for example it's recommended in Java to private most internal variables and methods, however this may not be the best solution for OSS. I open this ticket to maybe start a rule to remove all "private" & "default"  modifiers from the source as this greatly limit our ability to customize the classes without the need of manual copy & paste the whole class (in some cases this is not even an option).

A quick example would be HorizontalGroup.computeSize() & HorizontalGroup.layoutWrapped() they both are private and I can't modify them. In this class it's possible to duplicate the whole class (but bad for future compatibility), but Label.computePrefSize() is more problematic example, Label is being used in other components such as Buttons, Tables, etc, so we can't even duplicate the class and modify it. 

I highly recommend marking all internal variables and methods with "protected" modifier. 

I know this may not be an "Issue" but I think this will reduce issues in the future and allow users to fix their issues themselves.
